comments.body:
I suggest we s/[package]/[Dart package]/ to be consistent with the the package type phrasing here:
https://flutter.io/docs/development/packages-and-plugins/developing-packages#package-types
Do we want to link deeply to https://flutter.io/docs/development/packages-and-plugins/developing-packages#developing-dart-packages ?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +6,10 @@
This project is a starting point for a Dart
[package](https://flutter.io/developing-packages/),
a library module containing code that can be shared easily across
multiple Flutter or Dart projects.

comments.body: I'd like to suggest we also add a section for "Support level". This is meant to describe if the package takes community contributions (PRs), and how responsive users should expect the publisher to be around issues.

I think the `##Additional information` section implies it? 

We can add to the [writing package pages](https://dart.dev/guides/libraries/writing-package-pages) doc that authors are encouraged to add a support level.
I guess I think of *Additional information* as miscellaneous content that is optional. I'm suggesting packages should be encouraged to always specify what their support level is.

The _Additional Information_ section says “Tell users where to go next, how to leave feedback, etc.”

What about updating it into: “Tell users more about the package: where to find more information, how to contribute to the package, how to file issues, what response they can expect from the package authors, and more.”

If we want to _require_ authors to specify a support level, I think it’s better to make it a line in `pubspec.yaml`, so that it’s displayed in the metadata, instead of adding a separate section in the README.

I don't think we can add this to the pubspec, as we don't have any kind of structured format for this.

I think your text suggestion can work for now.
